children.text: Pricing Calculator: How to price your product

Setting the right price for your product can can boost sales volume, increase your market share, and steal potential customers from your competitors. This template breaks down how to set your optimal price based on five steps.
Customize by customer and market profile

Set your Target Margin
6. (Optional) Adjust price for discounts
Take into account the materials or inputs required to create your product. Add your costs to the below table. Add/remove as many rows as you need.
Now, let's estimate how much it will cost to package and ship a product. As shipping costs will vary by order size, we've created multiple shipping packages.
Your current order cost is now

It's common to adjust pricing based on the terms of payment to create incentives for your business. For example, it might make sense to be paid in a specific currency or get payed upfront. Update the below table to your needs:
Payment upfront before receiving any goods or services
Letter of Credit at Sight: payment after all contigencies
Letter of Credit 180 days: Simillar to LC Sight but the payment is set 180 after all contigencies
Payment clears after specific documents are received by the buyer
You may also want  to add premium for payment in certain currencies if that incurs additional costs:
Your current exchange rate buffer is
and your term of payments adjustment is set at
Depending on the customer segment and region, you might want to adapt your prices. Here we adapt pricing based on region, but you can augment this model with additional categories.
5. Set Your Target Margin and Price Point
Finally, you can set your target profit margin to calculate your optimal price given your costs, shipping, payment terms and customer profile
Include any discounts you may be offering to understand how those discounts will effect your final price. You can customize these inputs with your scenario.
